image.altText: Powerlines built through a clearing in a forest

props.synopsis: The South Australian government is urgently seeking to restart two mothballed diesel-powered generators as it warns the state is at risk of blackouts this summer.

title.children: SA government seeks new powers to get diesel generators back online ahead of peak summer period

image.altText: close up of parking machine with lawns in the background

props.synopsis: Machines that require a person's number plate, do not accept cash, and will only issue digital receipts have been installed to replace nearly 300 ticket machines rendered obsolete as the 3G network shut down.

title.children: Rego requirements, digital receipts prompt privacy fears over cashless parking machines

image.altText: The sun beams through buildings on Adelaide's Hindley Street.

props.synopsis: With parts of the country already sweltering though heatwaves, support services are worried many people will not be able to afford to keep cool this year.

title.children: Above-average temperatures for summer prompt concerns more Australians at risk of heat-related injuries

image.altText: Peter Malinauskas speaking on stage to a crowd

props.synopsis: The South Australian parliament has backed laws to strip money out of politics â€“ essentially, out of their own pockets. So how did the bill attract broad political support?

title.children: Taking money out of politics by dipping deeper into the public purse

image.altText: A man in a yellow and blue shirt sits in a dialysis chair receiving treatment

props.synopsis: Edwin Foster drives a round-trip of 250 kilometres three times a week for kidney dialysis treatment. He's one of thousands rural Australians travelling long distances for the life-saving treatment.

title.children: Rural dialysis patients travelling thousands of kilometres a year to reach treatment

image.altText: Man in a judge's wig and uniform with a purple sash, looking into a mirror.

props.synopsis: From musical outcast to Judge to cult punk rock favourite. Judge Simon Stretton has bucked several trends across duelling careers.

title.children: Once 'hated, ignored and rejected', this little-known punk rock band led by a former judge has found a cult following

image.altText: Three young women stand in front of a large tree smiling. The lady in the middle holds a baby kangaroo in a pink pouch

props.synopsis: Regional veterinary jobs are taking more than 12 months to fill, but a Riverland clinic has found a short-term solution to boost workforce and mental health outcomes.

title.children: There are lots of snakes and it's 'the size of Belgium', but this region desperately needs its foreign vets

image.altText: A bettong wrapped inside a cream coloured soft bag

props.synopsis: After being driven to extinction in the area, these tiny brush-tailed bettongs were reintroduced to South Australia's Yorke Peninsula as part of an ambitious project to help nature heal itself â€” and evidence of their eco-engineering can already be seen.

title.children: The tiny engineers helping nature heal itself

image.altText: A view from behind of military graduates in full dress uniform, marching.

props.synopsis: Legislative changes will be enacted to establish a new oversight body as the government accepts several proposals including mandatory discharge for sexual offences.

title.children: Diggers to be discharged for sexual offences as government implements most royal commission recommendations

image.altText: A man wearing a blue shir, black hat and sunglasses holding a carton of eggs in a field.

props.synopsis: Blasting AC/DC and sorting through hundreds of eggs is how Jinda Holland spends most of his working days. At 39, it is one of only a handful of jobs he has ever had and it is his favourite by far.

title.children: The chicken farm giving people living with disability a crack at the job market, one egg at a time

image.altText: Donald Trump points his finger while partially poking his tongue out

props.synopsis: As the US president-elect threatens to make it costly for a group of nine developing nations to drop the US dollar as their go-to currency for international trade, we look at whether they have the capacity to actually do so.

title.children: Trump threatens BRICS nations with 100pc tariffs over currency plans

image.altText: Rooftop solar with powerlines in background

props.synopsis: With the rise and rise of rooftop solar showing no signs of stopping in Australia, the market operator says "emergency" powers to control it are urgently needed.

title.children: Market operator says emergency powers needed to switch off panels as solar tsunami 'threatens wipeout'

image.altText: Close-up of the cocaine bricks.

props.synopsis: Police have made the largest cocaine seizure in Australian history following an investigation into a transnational organised crime syndicate accused of conspiring to import more than two tonnes of the drug into Australia.

title.children: Comanchero bikie leader charged over bungled attempt to bring 2.34 tonnes of cocaine into Australia

image.altText: A large red and white passenger ferry in a body of water against a wintery backdrop

props.synopsis: The Spirit of Tasmania IV ferry is making its way across the North Sea to its temporary home in Scotland, but taxpayers are yet to learn how much it will cost to remain there.

title.children: As the newest Spirit of Tasmania ferry heads to its temporary home in Scotland, berthing costs remain unknown

image.altText: Woman putting bread into a toaster in a small kitchen.

props.synopsis: There's pressure on the government to fund and build more social and affordable housing, with one insider describing the shortage as "extremely severe".

title.children: Rebecca is living in a hotel with five kids while they wait for social housing

image.altText: Supreme Court WA

props.synopsis: The four people accused of murdering Perth schoolboy Cassius Turvey formally enter pleas of not guilty in WA's Supreme Court.

title.children: Four people accused of murdering Cassius Turvey plead not guilty in Supreme Court

image.altText: Chickens stick their heads out from cages at a farm.

props.synopsis: Australia's surveillance of bird flu has been described as a possible "model" to follow globally, with the spread of the H5N1 strain of the virus causing concerns for international health authorities.

title.children: There's only one continent without the deadly H5N1 bird flu strain. The approach might make Australia a 'world leader'

image.altText: A composite image of Kim Jong Un, Donald Trump and Elon Musk.

props.synopsis: When Donald Trump re-enters the White House on January 20, he will find that Kim Jong Un, the man he so enjoyed meeting, has built for himself a new international status â€“ and is now a major ally of Vladimir Putin.Â

title.children: Trump has added another 'rocket man' to his friend list

image.altText: chihuahua sat in a trolley wearing a green shirt that says brat at new york dog parade

props.synopsis: Each year, a number of words rise above and define the feelings of so many people across the world, and each year the world's top dictionaries select a word as the best of the year.

title.children: From brat to enshittification and everything in between, these are the 2024 'words of the year'

image.altText: A man with grey hair in a navy suit looks serious.

props.synopsis: University of Canberra interim vice-chancellor Stephen Parker, who was brought on in September to prepare a 2025 budget addressing the university's difficult financial position, has resigned from the role.

title.children: University of Canberra vice-chancellor resigns, citing 'lost confidence in council'

props.synopsis: As more cracks appear in the burgeoning super industry, performance won't take centre stage. The trust gap will.

title.children: New battleground starting to open up over superannuation

image.altText: An light-skinned Arab man in his 50s sits at a desk with Syrian Arab Republic on a placard in front of him

props.synopsis: A government counterinsurgency recaptures several towns that had been overrun in recent days by rebels, the army says, as Russian strikes kill at least 19 people.

title.children: Syrian president vows to 'crush' rebels as Russian air strikes pummel Idlib

image.altText: Travis Head removes his gloves after being dismissed

props.synopsis: Travis Head is confident Australia can work its way back into the series against India and says there is no sign of a feud between the team's batters and bowlers.

title.children: Head expects Australia to bounce back from Perth thrashing for second Test

image.altText: A bolt of lightning shoots across the sky in front of a partial rainbow arc

props.synopsis: Some parts of New South Wales had more than 50 millimetres of rain over the weekend, but it took much less than that to create the strange pairing of lightning and rainbows at Wagga Wagga.

title.children: Lightning cuts across a rainbow in rare and 'short-lived phenomena'

image.altText: A woman wearing white shirt with frilled collar speaks, in front of a window

props.synopsis: The New South Wales Health Secretary offers an apology to women who have been affected by recent abortion bans, adding that she has written to hospital executives across the state reminding them of their responsibilities.

title.children: Health secretary apologises to women across NSW who were unable to access abortion care

image.altText: A colonial-looking lounge room with leather couches, a fire place and red carpet

props.synopsis: The 163-year-old Tasmanian Club has, after much fuss, voted to overturn a rule excluding women from the bar â€” but before you ladies begin queuing up for a peek inside, please note â€” you'll still need to be accompanied by a gentleman.

title.children: Women now permitted in the bar at the Tasmanian Club â€” but they have to be with a man

image.altText: two people speaking at a hearing

props.synopsis: A Queensland youth organisation has described children leaving detention centres as a "sacrificial lamb", as public hearings for the state government's crime law changes get underway.

title.children: 'Sacrificial lamb': Queensland youth group calls out justice system failures as new laws face public hearings

image.altText: A sign on the front of a building saying 'Genius Childcare', photographed through bars.

props.synopsis: More than a dozen staff at Genius Childcare centres in the ACT have resigned while others have taken stress leave amid allegations of ongoing pay delays.

title.children: Mass resignations at national childcare chain over allegations staff aren't being paid on time

image.altText: A man in an Australia yellow running jersey runs.

props.synopsis: Andy Buchanan, a late replacement for the Paris Olympics, took over a minute off the previous Australian Marathon record on a fast course in Valencia, while Izzi Batt-Doyle ran the third-fastest time by an Australian woman in history.

title.children: 'The guy from Bendigo that does a bit of running' smashes Australian marathon record

image.altText: The Roblox app displayed on a smartphone screen with a Roblox logo in the background.

props.synopsis: Roblox is one of the most popular platforms in the world, but there are increasing concerns over the ability for users to message each other directly through games, with young children being lured off-platform and exposed to disturbing content.Â

title.children: 'Very naive': Mum's warning after her nine-year-old was targeted by a predator on Roblox

image.altText: Albanese sits at the centre table in parliament, frowning as he looks up from paperwork

props.synopsis: In an ominous sign for the government, new research shows dissatisfaction with the direction of the country is at the same level as it was just before the Morrison government lost the election.

title.children: A freight train of voter anger might be about to hit Albanese

image.altText: A person's thumb edges towards a Facebook app icon on a smartphone.

props.synopsis: Under two new changes, financial advertisers on Facebook and Instagram will be required to reveal who is paying for the ads and who benefits from them.

title.children: Meta announces new rules for financial advertisers in bid to crack down on celebrity scam ads

image.altText: A roll of copper cable.

props.synopsis: WA's Main Roads department says well-organised thieves are increasingly targeting copper wire in street lights. The latest hit has affected an 1,800 metre stretch of cycle path in Mirrabooka.

title.children: 'One step ahead of us': Crooks steal 15,000m of cabling as WA grapples with increase in copper theft

image.altText: Houses in Brisbane street

props.synopsis: National home prices are losing momentum, new data shows, and anticipated interest rate cuts are unlikely to stop falls in house prices next year.

title.children: 'A strain on households': Property market continues to lose steam and house price falls are expected for 2025

image.altText: A sign with LGH and emergency written on it.

props.synopsis: Survivors of alleged historical child sexual abuse at a Tasmanian hospital have received a combined $7.85 million settlement, with one claimant saying that while no money could remedy the abuse, it was "life-changing".

title.children: Survivors of paedophiles working at Tasmanian hospital receive $7.85 million compensation
